The case was filed by Sri K esavananda Bharati (head of a Hindu religious mutt in Kerala), challenging the constitutional validity of the 24th, 25th and 29th Amendments to the Indian Constitution. Romesh Thappar vs State of Madras: Freedom of speech and expression includes Freedom of press. AK Gopalan vs State of Madras - Deals with the constitutionality of preventive detention. Sajjan Singh vs State of Rajasthan - Involved a challenge to the validity of the Constitution (26th Amendment) Act.

question: Q.358. The State of K erala Vs Leesamma Joseph case deals with __________. SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (2nd shift)
options: ['(a) dowry ', '(b) the economic weaker section ', '(c) education ', '(d) persons with disabilities ']
solution: Sol.358.(d) persons with disabilities. This case was r elated to Article 16 (equal opportunity in the workplace). The SC held that persons with physical disabilities have the right to reservation in promotions. Other Important Cases - Kesavananda Bharati case: T he Supreme Court gave the doctrine of the ‘Basic Structure’ of the constitution. Shayara Bano vs Union of India : The Supreme Court struck down the practice of triple talaq and declared it unconstitutional.

question: Q.359. The Supreme Court of India came into existence on ___________ . SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (2nd shift)
options: ['(a) 30 January 1935 ', '(b) 26 January 1950 ', '(c) 15 August 1947 ', '(d) 2 October 1952 ']
solution: Sol.359.(b) 26 January 1 950. 50th Chief Justice of India: Dhananjaya Y. Chandrachud. On January 28, 1950, two days after India became a Sovereign Democratic Republic, the Supreme Court was inaugurated in the Chamber of Princes in the Parliament building. The foundation stone of the Supreme Court's building was laid on 29 October 1954 by Rajendra Prasad, the first President of India. The proceedings of the Supreme Court are conducted in English language only. A person who has been a Judge of the Supreme Court is debarred from practising in any court of law or before any other authority in India.

question: Q.360. Till which year did the High Court of Delhi continue to exercise jurisdiction over Himachal Pradesh? SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution: Sol.360.(c) 1971. The Indian High Courts Act (1861) established High Courts of Calcutta, Madras and Bombay. The first high court of India was established in Kolkata and formally it was called the High Court of Judicature at Fort William. India has 25 High Courts (now). Article 214 - High Court for each State. Article 226 - Power of h igh court to issue certain writs. Article 216 - Constitution of High Court.

question: Q.361. Which of the following statements are true regarding the Family Courts (Amendment) Bill, 2022? Graduate Level 27/06/2023 (Shift - 4) 1. The Family Courts (Amendment) Bill was introduced in Lok Sabha on 18 July 2022. 2. The Bill amends the Family Courts Act, 1984. 3. The Act allows state governments to establish Family Courts. 4. The Act is not applicable in Punjab and Tamil Nadu.
solution: Sol.361.(a) 1, 2 and 3. Family Courts (Amendment) Bill 2022 seeks to amend the Family Courts Act, 1984 to establish family courts in H imachal Pradesh and Nagaland. Family Court Act, 1984 - Enacted for the establishment of Family Courts with a view to promote conciliation, and secure speedy settlement of disputes relating to marriage and family affairs and for related matters. Appointment of J udges - The State Government may, with the concurrence of the High Court, appoint one or more persons to be the Judge or Judges of a Family Court.

question: Q.362. The High court of Delhi was established in _______. SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Evening)
solution: Sol.362.(d) 1966. The High Court of Delhi was established with four Judges. They were Chief Justice K.S.Hegde, Justice I.D. Dua, Justice H.R.Khanna and Justice S.K.Kapur. Presently, the sanctioned strength of Judges of the High Court of Delhi is 45 permanent Judges and 15 Additional Judges. Chief Justice of Delhi High court (As of June 2023) - Satish Chandra Sharma. Before 1966 under the States Reorganisation Act, 1 956 Delhi was u nder the jurisdiction of the Punjab High Court.

question: Q.363. In the Indian Judicial system, PIL stands for ___________. SSC MTS 16/05/2023 (Evening)
options: ['(a) Public Interest Litigation ', '(b) Periodic Individual Litigation ', '(c) Private Interest Licence ', '(d) Periodic Interest Litigation ']
solution: Sol.363.(a) Public Interest Litigation. It refers to litigation undertaken to secure public interest and demonstrates the availability of justice to socially - disadvantaged parties and was introduced by Justice P. N. Bhagwati. It is a relaxation of the traditional rule of locus standi.

question: Q.364. The first High Court in India was established in ______________ . SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Morning)
solution: Sol.364.(b) 1862 . Calcutta High Court: It was brought into existence under the High Court's Act (1861). Location - Esplanade Row West (Kolkata). Jurisdiction - West Bengal and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands. Bombay High Court {(14 August 1862) (Indian High Courts Act 1861)}, Madras High Court {(15 August 1862, Indian High Courts Act 1861}.

question: Q.365. In which of the following cases did the Supreme Court o f India pronounce the theory of the ‘Basic Structure’ of the Constitution? SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (4th Shift)
options: ['(a) Kesavananda Bharati Case, 1973 ', '(b) Golaknath Case, 1967 ', '(c) Minerva Mills Case, 1980 ', '(d) Swarn Singh Case, 1989 ']
solution: Sol.365.(a) Kesavananda Bharati Case, 1973 - Parliament can n ot amend or a lter the ‘Basic Structure’ of the constitution. Golaknath Case, 1967 - Parliament cannot take away or abridge any of the Fundamental Rights. Minerva Mills Case, 1980 - Parliament can a mend any part of the Constitution but it cannot change the “Basic Structure” of the Constitution. Swarn Singh Case, 1998 - In this case, the SC held the UP Governor's pardon of a convict unconstitutional.

question: Q.366. What is the structure of t he Indian judiciary? SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (4th Shift)
options: ['(a) One-tier ', '(b) Two-tier ', '(c) Three-tier ', '(d) Five-tier ']
solution: Sol.366.(c) Three-tier. The structure of the judiciary - Supreme Court (Article 124) at the top, High Courts (Article 214) below them and session’s courts at the lowest level. Article 141 (Law d eclared by Supreme Court to be binding on all courts). Writs issued by Supreme Court (Article 32) and HIgh Court (226).

question: Q.367. A judge of t he Supreme Court can be removed only on the grounds of ______ SSC CGL 09/12/2022 (1st Shift)
options: ['(a) disrespect of the Constitution ', '(b) proven misbehaviour or incapacity ', '(c) murder charges ', '(d) lack of knowledge ']
solution: Sol.367.(b) Proven misbehaviour or incapacity. Article 124 - There shall be a Supreme Court of India. Article 143 - Power of the President to consult the Supreme Court.

question: Q.368. Which of the following jurisdictions of t he Supreme Court allows it to settle disputes between the centre and state and amongst states? SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (4th Shift)
options: ['(a) Appellate ', '(b) Advisory ', '(c) Writ ', '(d) Original ']
solution: Sol.368.(d) Original. The Supreme Court (Articles 124 to 147, Part V) has Original (Article 131), Appellate (Article 133-136), and Advisory (Article 143) jurisdiction. Under Original Jurisdiction, SC can hear the following cases: Any dispute between the Indian Government and one or more States, Any dispute between the Indian Government and one or more States on one side and one or more States on the other side, Any dispute between two or more States.

question: Q.369. A Supreme Court or High Court judge can be removed by the Parliament by: SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Afternoon)
options: ['(a) simple majority ', '(b) both simple and two third majority ', '(c) special majority ', '(d) two third majority ']
solution: Sol.369.(c) Special majority. Special majority as per Article 249 requires a majority of 2/3rd members present and voting. For example, if out of the 245 members in Rajya Sabha, only 150 are present and voting, then the special majority required as per Article 249 would be 101. Simple majority refers to a majority of more than 50% of the members present and voting in the House. Majorities in the Constitution can be categorised into four Types : Absolute, Effective, Simple and Special.

question: Q.370. Which is NOT correct about the independence of the judiciary in our country? SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon)
options: ['(a) The judiciary has the power to penalise those who are found guilty of contempt of court. ', '(b) The judges are financially dependent on both the executive and legislature for their salaries and allowances. ', '(c) The Constitution prescribes a very difficult procedure for removal of judges. ', '(d) The legislature is not involved in the process of appointment of judges. ']
answer: (b) The judges are financially dependent on both the executive and legislature for their salaries and allowances.
solution: Sol.370.(b) Judges salaries and allowances are fixed and not subject to legislative approval. Supreme Court Judges {The Salaries, Pension and Allowances are charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India (Article 266 (1)}, High Court Judges {Salaries and Allowances are charged upon the Consolidated Fund of the States and the Pension is charged on the Consolidated Fund of India} .

question: Q.371. The Indian judicial system is based on: SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon)
options: ['(a) both integrated and dual system ', '(b) dual court system ', '(c) multiple court system ', '(d) single integrated system ']
solution: Sol.371.(d) single integrated system. The judiciary is the watchdog of democracy, and also the guardian of the Constitution. Structure of Indian Judiciary {Supreme Court at the top, High Courts are below the SC, and below them are the district and subordinate courts}. Supreme Court {Articles (124 - 147), Chapter IV, Part V}, High Courts {Articles (214 - 231), Chapter V, part VI}, Subordinate courts {Articles (233 - 237), Chapter VI, Part VI}.

question: Q.372. Who among the following is NOT a part of the Union Executive? SSC CHSL 25/05/2022 (Afternoon)
options: ['(a) The Prime Minister of India ', '(b) The President of India ', '(c) The Supreme Court of India ', '(d) The council of ministers ']
solution: Sol.372.(c) Supreme Court of I ndia is the highest constitutional court, and h as the power of judicial review. It was established on 26 January 1950. H.J.Kania was the first chief justice of the Supreme Court. Article 124: Establishment and Constitution of Supreme Court. Government Bodies

question: Q.373. What is the maximum age for a member of a joint public service commission to hold his/her office as per the Constitution of India ? SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Evening)
options: ['(a) 62 years ', '(b) 66 years ', '(c) 65 years ', '(d) 60 years ']
solution: Sol.373.(a) 62 years. Joint State Public Service Commission (JSPSC) - It can b e created by an act of Parliament at the request of the state legislatures concerned. It is a statutory body. Its chairman is appointed by the President. A member of a Public Service Commission shall hold office for a term of six years. In the case of the Union Commission, his or her minimum age is 65 years to attain the office.

question: Q.374. Who was the first chairman of Finance Commission of India? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)
options: ['(a) K Santhanam ', '(b) KC Neogy ', '(c) Ashok Kumar Chanda ', '(d) PV Rajamannar ']
solution: Sol.374.(b) KC Neogy. The Finance Commission of India is an independent constitutional body that is set up by the President of India after every five years o r earlier to make recommendations on the distribution of financial resources between the Union and the states. The recommendations of FCs are advisory in nature and not binding on the Union government. Article 280 - Finance Commission. Chairman of 16th Finance Commission of India - Arvind Panagariya.

question: Q.375. Under which o f t he following Acts was the National Commission for Women established? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)
options: ['(a) The National Commission for Women Act, 1988 ', '(b) The National Commission for Women Act, 1990 ', '(c) The National Commission for Women Act, 1989 ', '(d) The National Commission for Women Act, 1987 ']
answer: (b) The National Commission for Women Act, 1990
solution: Sol.375.(b) The National Commission for Women is a statutory body set up in January 1992 under the National Commission for Women Act, 1990 to review the constitutional and legal safeguards for women; recommend remedial legislative measures; facilitate redressal of grievances and advise the Government on all policy matters affecting women. The First Commission was constituted on 31st January 1992 with Mrs. Jayanti Patnaik as the Chairperson.

question: Q.376. Which of the following is responsible for attending to disputes concerning recruitment and conditions of service of public personnel at the Centre? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Afternoon)
options: ['(a) Central Administrative Tribunal ', '(b) The Settlement and Appellate Tribunal ', '(c) The Competition Appellate Tribunal ', '(d) Joint Administrative Tribunal ']
solution: Sol.376.(a) Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT) - It is a Statutory body, established under Administrative Tribunals Act, 1985. It comes under the purview of Article 323-A (Added by 42nd amendment act 1976). Its chairman and members are appointed by the President after consulting the Chief justice of India.

question: Q.377. Which of t he following is a duty o f the Attorney General of India? SSC MTS 01/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
options: ['(a) To give advice to the Government of India on legal matters ', '(b) To act as a judge in the Supreme Court ', '(c) To advise the State Government ', '(d) To represent India in international bodies ']
answer: (a) To give advice to the Government of India on legal matters
solution: Sol.377.(a) Attorney General (AG) of India (Article-76) - He is a part of the Union Executive and the highest law officer of the country. Appointed by the President on the advice of the government. Term of O ffice - Not fixed by the constitution. They can take part in the proceedings of both houses of parliament without voting rights.

question: Q.378. Who appoints the State Election Commissioner ? SSC MTS 04/09/2023 (1st Shift)
options: ['(a) Governor ', '(b) Speaker ', '(c) Chief Minister ', '(d) Advocate General ']
solution: Sol.378.(a) Governor. The State Election Commissioner (SEC) is appointed by the Governor on the recommendation of a collegium, comprising the Chief Minister, the Speaker of the State Legislative Assembly and the Leader of Opposition in the Legislative Assembly. Power of SEC - To conduct free, fair and impartial elections to the local bodies in the state.

question: Q.379. Who conducts elections for both the houses of Parliament in India? SSC MTS 04/09/2023 (2nd Shift)
options: ['(a) Ministry of Parliamentary Affairs ', '(b) Election Commission ', '(c) President ', '(d) Prime Minister ']
solution: Sol.379.(b) Election Commission - established in 1950. Part XV Election Commission (324 - 329): Article 326 - Elections to the House of t he People and to the Legislative Assemblies of States to be on the basis of adult suffrage.

question: Q.380. Which of the following is NOT a constitutional body? SSC MTS 14/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
options: ['(a) Election Commission ', '(b) Finance Commission ', '(c) Union Public Service Commission ', '(d) NITI Aayog ']
solution: Sol.380.(d) NITI Aayog (National Institution for Transforming India) is a Premier policy ‘Think tank’ of the Government of India. It was established on January 1, 2015, to replace the Planning Commission. Aims - Promote cooperative federalism by facilitating collaboration and constructive engagement between the central government and state governments. Finance Commission - Established (22 November 1951). Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) - Established (1 October 1926). Election Commission - Established (25 January 1950).

question: Q.381. In India, which M inistry issues the coins of all denominations? SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (1st shift)
options: ['(a) Ministry of External Affairs ', '(b) Ministry of Home Affairs ', '(c) Ministry of Mines ', '(d) Ministry Of Finance ']
solution: Sol.381.(d) Ministry of Finance. The Government of India has the sole right to mint coins. The responsibility for c oinage vests with the Government of India in accordance with the Coinage Act, 1906 as amended from time to time. The designing and minting of c oins in various denominations is also the responsibility of the Government of India. Coins are minted at the four Indian Government Mints at Mumbai, Alipore(Kolkata), Saifabad (Hyderabad), Cherlapally (Hyderabad) and Noida (UP). It is issued for circulation only through the Reserve Bank in terms of the RBI Act.

question: Q.382. Who i s the Administrative Head of the Indian Audit and Accounts Department ? SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (1st shift)
options: ['(a) Accountant General ', '(b) Principal Accountant General ', '(c) Director General ', '(d) The Comptroller and Auditor General ']
solution: Sol.382.(d) The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG). A rticle 148 - There shall be a Comptroller and Auditor General of India who shall be appointed by the President and shall only be removed from office in like manner and on like grounds as a Judge of the Supreme Court. CAG audits all receipts and expenditure of the Government of India and the State Governments, including those of autonomous bodies and corporations substantially financed by the Government. Term - 6 years or up to 65 years of age (whichever is earlier).

question: Q.383. Which of the following statements are correct regarding the Union Public Service Commission? A. The Parliament has the power to make regulations as to conditions of s ervice of the Chairman, members and staff of the commission. B. The Government of India Act, 1935, envisaged a Public Service Commission for the Federation and a Provincial Public Service Commission for e ach P rovince or group of Provinces. C. The Federal Public Service Commission came to be known as the Union Public Service Commission by virtue of Clause (1) of Article 378 of the Constitution in 1950. SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (1st shift)
options: ['(a) A and B only ', '(b) A, B and C ', '(c) B and C only ', '(d) A and C only ']
solution: Sol.383.(c) B and C only. The President has the power to make regulations as to conditions of service of the Chairman, members and staff of the commission. Union public service commission (UPSC) : Established on - 1 October 1926. Articles 315 to 323 (Part XIV) - Provides for the establishment of a Public S ervice Commission for the Union and a Public Service Commission for each State. Work - Recruiting civil servants. The first chairman of UPSC in independent India was H. K. Kripalani.

question: Q.384. The Chairman of a State Public Service Commission can be removed by the order of the __________ . SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (3rd shift)
options: ['(a) Prime Minister ', '(b) President ', '(c) Governor ', '(d) Chief Minister ']
solution: Sol.384.(b) President. Provisions regarding the composition of SPSC provided in Part XIV of the Article 315 - 323. Article 317: Removal and suspension of a member of both the UPSC or SPSC. A rticle 316 (Appointment and terms of office of Members) : The Chairman and other members of the SPSC are appointed by the Governor of the State. Term of Office: A member of the SPSC shall hold office for a term of six years or till the age of 62 years, whichever is earlier.

question: Q.385. Which of the following statements is/are correct regarding the Finance Commission of India? A. The Finance Commission consists of a Chairman and four other members. B. The recommendations made by the Finance Commission are binding on the government and government needs to grant funds according to the advice of the Commission. C. Article 280 of the Indian Constitution talks about the recommendations of the Finance Commission. SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (4th shift)
options: ['(a) A and B only ', '(b) A, B and C ', '(c) A only ', '(d) B and C only ']
solution: Sol.385.(c) A only. Finance Commission (FC) is a constitutional body under Article 280. It is set up after every five years or earlier to make recommendations on the distribution of financial resources between the Union and the states. The recommendations o f FCs are advisory in nature and not binding on the Union government. The Union government notifies the acceptance of the recommendations through a Presidential Order, which also specifies the period for which they are valid (usually five years) and also tables an explanatory memorandum in Parliament.

question: Q.386. Which of the following is NOT a Constitutional Body in India? Higher Secondary 28/06/2023 (Shift - 2)
options: ['(a) Election Commission of India ', '(b) State Human Rights Commission ', '(c) State Public Service Commission ', '(d) Union Public Service Commission of India ']
solution: Sol.386.(b) State Human Rights Commission - It is a Statutory body, established under protection of human right act 1993. The Chairman and the members of the State Commission are appointed by the Governor. Tenure - Three years or till they reach the age of 70 years.

question: Q.387. In which year did the Election Commission of India for the first time in its history become a multi member body? Matric Level 28/06/2023 (Shift - 4)
solution: Sol.387.(d) 1989. The Election Commission of India (ECI) is a constitutional body. The Election Commissioner Amendment Act, 1989 (adopted on 1 January 1990) turned the commission into a 3-member Commission. The ECI body administers elections to the Lok Sabha, Rajya Sabha, State Legislative Assemblies, State Legislative Councils and the offices of the President and the Vice President of the country.

question: Q.388. The Gram Sabha is a meeting of all adults who live in the area covered by a___________. SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Afternoon)
options: ['(a) district ', '(b) city ', '(c) state ', '(d) panchayat ']
solution: Sol.388.(d) Panchayat. The term Gram Sabha is defined in the Constitution of India under Article 243(b). Gram Sabha i s the primary body of the Panchayati Raj system and by far the largest. It is a permanent body. The power to annul a decision of the Gram Sabha rests with the Gram Sabha only. Related Articles - 243A - Constitution of Gram Sabha.

question: Q.389. The Bureau of Indian Standard is a statutory body working u nder the aegis of which union ministry? SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (4th Shift)
options: ['(a) Ministry of Commerce and Industry ', '(b) Ministry of Micro, Small & Medium Enterprises ', '(c) Ministry of Corporate Affairs ', '(d) Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution ']
answer: (d) Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution
solution: Sol.389.(d) The Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution . It operates various schemes like Product Certification (ISI mark), Management Systems Certification, Hallmarking of Gold and Silver Jewellery/Artefacts and Laboratory Services. B ureau of Indian Standards (BIS), earlier known as the Indian Standards Institution (ISI), was founded in 1947. The BIS Act 2016, established the BIS as the National Standards Body of India. BIS recently celebrated its 75th anniversary.

question: Q.390. Which of the following is NOT one of the objectives of the NITI Aayog? SSC CHSL 13/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
options: ['(a) To develop mechanisms to formulate credible plans at the village level ', '(b) To design and print new currency notes and to bring them in circulation ', '(c) To pay special attention to the sections of our society that may be at risk of not benefiting adequately from economic progress. ', '(d) To evolve a shared vision of national development priorities ']
answer: (b) To design and print new currency notes and to bring them in circulation
solution: Sol.390.(b) NITI Aayog: National Institution for Transforming India, Established: 1 January 2015, Chairman: Prime Minister of India, First Chairman: Narendra Modi, First CEO (Chief Executive Officer): Sindhushree Khullar, First Vice - Chairperson: Arvind Panagariya.

question: Q.391. The Comptroller and Auditor General of India is a: SSC CGL 02/12/2022 (1st Shift)
options: ['(a) two - member body ', '(b) three - member body ', '(c) single - member body ', '(d) six - member body ']
solution: Sol.391.(c) single-member body. Article 148 broadly deals with the CAG appointment, oath and conditions of service. He is the head of t he Indian audit & account department and chief Guardian of Public purse. He is not a member of the parliament.

question: Q.392. The elections to the Panchayati Raj institutions are conducted by the ________. SSC CGL 05/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
options: ['(a) Central election commission ', '(b) State government ', '(c) State election commission ', '(d) Central government ']
solution: Sol.392.(c) State election commission functions - Conducting elections to the Panchayati Raj institutions, Preparation of Electoral Rolls, Appointment of Dates for Nominations, Fixing Time for Poll, Counting of Votes, etc.

question: Q.393. The State Finance Commission is appointed every_____ years by the_______ SSC CGL 09/12/2022 (4th Shift)
options: ['(a) 5, state government ', '(b) 5, central government ', '(c) 2.5, state government ', '(d) 2.5, central government ']
solution: Sol.393.(a) 5, state government . According to Article 243 (I), the Governor of a State shall establish a State Finance Commission (constitutional body) every 5 years (73 r d Amendment Act 1992). It distributes state resources to Panchayati Raj institutions at all three levels in the form of taxes, duties, and levies to be collected by the state and local governments.

question: Q.394. In which year was the National Commission for Protection of Child Rights established? SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Morning)
solution: Sol.394.(b) 2007. The National Commission for Protection of Child Rights (NCPCR) is an Indian statutory body established by an Act of Parliament, the Commission for Protection of Child Rights (CPCR) Act, 2005. The Commission works under the aegis of Ministry of Women and Child Development, GoI.

question: Q.395. What is the tenure of the Chairperson of National Human Rights Commission? Graduate Level 03/08/2022 (Shift - 3)
options: ['(a) Three Years ', '(b) Five Years ', '(c) Six Years ', '(d) Four Years ']
solution: Sol.395.(a) Three years (or until they attain the age of 70 years). National Human Rights Commission: Statutory body, Founded: 12 October, 1993, Composition: chairperson, five full-time Members and seven deemed Members, Appointed by the President, Five Specialized Divisions: Law Division, Investigation Division, Policy Research & Programmes Division, Training Division and Administration Division.

question: Q.396. In which year was t he National Commission for Women established in India ? Higher Secondary 02/08/2022 (Shift - 2)
solution: Sol.396.(a) 1992. Other Commissions - The National Commission for Scheduled Castes (2004). National Commission for Scheduled Tribes (2004), National Commission for Minorities (1993), National Commission for Backward Classes (1993).

question: Q.397. What is the tenure of t he Election Commissioner of India? Higher Secondary 05/08/2022 (Shift - 2)
options: ['(a) Five Years ', '(b) Four Years ', '(c) Six Years ', '(d) Three Years ']
solution: Sol.397.(c) Six Years. Article 324 - The Election Commission shall consist of a Chief election commissioner and other two election commissioners. The tenure of t he Election Commissioner i s six years or up to the age of 6 5 years whichever is earlier. The Constitution does not prescribe terms for members of the election commission. It cannot be removed from his office e xcept i n the like manner and grounds as a judge of the supreme court.

question: Q.398. When was the Backward and Minority Communities Employees Federation (BAMCEF) established in India ? SSC CHSL 13/10/2020 (Afternoon)
solution: Sol.398.(c) 1978. The origin of BAMCEF lies in the organisation for employees of oppressed communities that was established in 1971 by Kanshi Ram, D. K. Khaparde and Dinabhai.

question: Q.399. The election to constitute a Panchayat should be completed before the expiration of a period of ______ from the date of its dissolution. SSC CHSL 14/10/2020 (Evening)

question: Q.444. What is the upper age limit for appointment as a judge of the High court as of October 2022? SSC MTS 19/06/2023 (Evening)

question: Q.445. Who presents the annual budget before the Lok Sabha? SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Afternoon)

question: Q.446. In which year was the Dowry Prohibition Act passed in India? SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (2nd Shift)

question: Q.503. In 1977, who became then President of the Janata Party, which formed a coalition government at the centre with Morarji Desai as the Prime Minister? SSC CGL 18/08/2021 (Afternoon)
options: ['(a) Charan Singh ', '(b) George Fernandes ', '(c) Chandra Shekhar ', '(d) Madhu Dandavate ']
solution: Sol.503.(c) Chandra Shekhar . He was President of the Janata Party from 1977 to 1988. Chandra Shekhar was sworn in as the ninth Prime Minister of India on November 10, 1991 and remained in office until June 21, 1991, for a period spanning 223 days.

question: Q.504. In which of the following states does the Governor have special responsibility under Article 371H of the Constitution with respect to law and order and in discharge of h is functions in relation thereto? SSC CGL 20/08/2021 (Morning)
options: ['(a) Nagaland ', '(b) Sikkim ', '(c) Mizoram ', '(d) Arunachal Pradesh ']
solution: Sol.504.(d) Arunachal Pradesh .

question: Q.505. Which of the following is the expanded form of the abbreviation 'Rep.' used in the text of the Constitution of India? SSC CGL 20/08/2021 (Evening)
options: ['(a) Repealed ', '(b) Republic ', '(c) Report ', '(d) Representative ']
solution: Sol.505.(a) Repealed . The meaning of Repeal is to rescind or annul by authoritative act; especially : to revoke or abrogate by legislative enactment.

question: Q.506. The Indian Forest Act 1927 was enacted after repealing which of the following Indian forest acts? SSC CGL 23/08/2021 (Morning)
options: ['(a) Indian Forest Act, 1882 ', '(b) Indian Forest Act, 1922 ', '(c) Indian Forest Act, 1865 ', '(d) Indian Forest Act, 1878 ']
solution: Sol.506.(d) Indian Forest Act, 1878. The Indian Forest Act of 1878 divided Indian forests into reserved forests (completely government-controlled), protected forests (partially government-controlled) and village forests (controlled by abutting villages).

question: Q.507. _ _ ____ is a set of norms and guidelines to be followed by the political parties and contesting candidates during election time. SSC CHSL 19/04/2021 (Afternoon)
options: ['(a) Constitutional Norms ', '(b) Constitutional Rules ', '(c) Code of Conduct ', '(d) Rigging ']
solution: Sol.507.(c) Code of Conduct is a set of rules outlining the norms, rules, and responsibilities or proper practices of an individual party or an organisation. The Model Code of C onduct c omes i nto force immediately on the announcement of t he election schedule by the commission for the need of ensuring free and fair elections . Its main purpose is to ensure that ruling parties, at the Centre and in the States, do not misuse their position of advantage to gain an unfair edge.

question: Q.508. In which year did the Central Government of India appoint the States Reorganisation Commission? SSC CHSL 05/08/2021 (Morning)
solution: Sol.508.(b) 1953. The States Reorganisation Commission (SRC) was constituted by the Central Government of India in December 1953 to recommend the reorganisation of state boundaries. States Reorganisation Commission consisted of F azal Ali, K. M . P anikkar and H. N. Kunzru. Its main recommendations were to organise states on a language basis as well a s the boundaries of state could reflect the linguistic aspects also.

question: Q.509. One-third of the members of the Vidhan Parishad retire every ______ years. SSC CHSL 06/08/2021 (Morning)
options: ['(a) four ', '(b) one ', '(c) three ', '(d) two ']
solution: Sol.509.(d) two years. Vidhan Parishad or Legislative Council is a permanent body, which can be formed or abolished when the Legislative Assembly passes a special resolution.

question: Q.510. Which was the first part of India to hold an election based on universal adult franchise? SSC CHSL 09/08/2021 (Morning)
options: ['(a) Assam ', '(b) Tripura ', '(c) Manipur ', '(d) Bihar ']
solution: Sol.510.(c) Manipur (June 1948). Maharaja of M anipur B odhchandra Singh signed the instrument of accession with the Indian government on the assurance that the internal autonomy of Manipur would be maintained.
